His sister, anxious for his safety, employed people to follow him, but they soon deserted him, fleeing from a pursuer more dangerous than any – from thought. His conduct, however, suddenly charged. Struck by the idea that he had left by his absence, the whole of his friends, with a friend among them, of whose presence they were unconscious, he determined to confront him again into society, and watch him closely, anxious to warn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Ruthven approached with intimacy. But when he entered into a room, his haggard and suspicious looks were so striking, his inward shudderings were so visible, that his sister was at last obliged to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, society which affected him so strongly. When remonſtration proved successful, the guardians thought it was high time to restore the trust imposed upon them by Aubrey’s parents.
30: Desiring to save him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encountered in his wandering life, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physician to reside in the house, and take constant care of him. He barely noticed it, so completely was his mind absorbed by one terrible subject. His incoherence became so great, that he was confined to his room. He would often lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had attained a glassy luster;—the only sign of affection and recollection remaining displayed itself upon her sister; then he sometimes started, and, seizing her hands, with looks that severely afflicted her, he would desire her not to touch her. When she inquired to whom he referred, his only answer was, “True! true!” and again he sank into a state, where even she couldn’t arouse him. The last many months passed gradually, however, as the year wore on, his incoherence became less frequent, and his mind broke off a portion of its gloom, while his guardians observed, that several times in the day he would count upon his fingers and then smile.
31: The lime had nearly passed, when, on the day of the year, one of his guardians entered his room, began to converse with his physician upon the melancholy circumstance of Avery’s being in such a sad situation, when his sister was going next day to be married. Aubrey’s attention was attracted; he asked who. They mentioned the Earl of Marsden. Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them even further by his expressing his irritation at being present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. His brother came with him in a few minutes. He was apparentably again capable of being asfected by the influence of her lovely smile; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing at the thought of her brother’s being once more alive to the feelings of affection. He began to speak with all his wanted warmth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage with a man so distinguished for rank and every accomplishment; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; opening it, what was his surprise at beholding the features of the monster who had so long influenced his life. He seized the portrait in a fit of rage, and staggered it beneath his foot. Upon her asking him why he thus destroyed the resemblance of her future busbarid, he looked as if he did not understand her—then he seized her hands, arid gazing on her with a suspicious expression of countcriance, he badeher swear that she would never wed this monster, for he— But he could not advance—it seemed as if that voice again bade her rememberhis oath—he turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthuen was near him but saw no one. The guardian and physician, who had heard the whole, and thought this words but a return of his disorder, entered, and summoning his spirit back to Miss Aubrey, desired her to leave him. He knelt down to them, begging them to delay but for one day. They attracted this to the insanity, they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavored to possess him, and retired.
32: Lord Ruthven had been refused by everyone else this morning. Where he heard of Aubrey’s illness, he quickly understood himself to be the cause of it, but when he learned that he was deemed insane, his elation and pleasure could hardly be concealed from those among whom he had gained this information. Having suffered to the house of his former companion, he gradually wore the ear of Miss Avery. He knew the serpent’s art, or fate’s will. The elder ranch fell to him, and he obtained an important embassy, which served as an excuse for hastening the marriage, (in spite of her brother’s deranged state, which was to take place the very day before his departure for the continent).
33: Aubrey, left by the physician and his guardians, assumed to bribe the servants, but in vain. He asked for a pen and paper; it was given to him; he wrote a letter to his sister, conveying her, as she valued her own happiness, her own sorrow, and the honor of those now in the grave, who once held her in their arms as their hope and the hope of their house, to delay but for a few hours that marriage, on which he condemned the most heavy curses. The doctors promised to deliver it; but refusing it to the physician, he thought it better not to harass Miss Aubrey’s mind with the ravings of a maniac. Night passed without rest to the busy inmates of the house, and Aubrey heard, with a horror that may more easily be conceived than described, the names of the men preparing. The morning came, and the sound of carriages broke upon his ear. Aubrey grew almost frantic. The servants’ curiosity finally overcame their vigilance, they gradually slowed away, leaving him in the custody of an helpless old woman. He seized the opportunity, with one bound, he was out of the room, and in a moment he found himself in the apartment where everyone was nearly assembled. Lord Ruthven immediately approached, and, seizing his arm with force, hurried away from the room, speechless with rage. Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear, “Remember your oath, and know, if not my bride to day, your sister is dishonored.” Women are frail; flying, he pushed him towards his relatives, who, roused by the old woman, had come to seek him. Aubrey could no longer support himself; his ravenet falling was broken, and he was conveyed to bed. The physician was afraid of upsetting his sister, who was not present when he entered. The marriage was solemnized, and the bride and groom left London.
34: Aubrey’s weakness increased; the swelling of blood produced symptoms of the near approach of death. He desired his summons’ guardians to be called, and when the midnight hour had struck, he related composedly what the reader had perceived – he died immediately after.
35: The guards hastened to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. Lord Ruthven had vanished, and Aubrey’s sister was overwhelmed by a vampire’s blood.
36:
“My Dearest Eleanor,

The island remains a solace, a balm to my troubled soul. Mitylene’s air, thick with the scent of salt and wild rosemary, washes away the echoes of London’s relentless clamor. I spend my days sketching the coastline, capturing the stark beauty of the cliffs and the restless sea. The solitude here is a rare and precious gift, a chance to reflect upon the triumphs and failures of a life spent chasing a fading dream. I’ve been sketching the Manor, a formidable structure of grey stone, reflecting the somber moods that often settle upon me. The servants are diligent, though their faces rarely hold a smile – a habit I’ve grown accustomed to, perhaps, to shield myself from the inevitable disappointment.  I find a strange comfort in the simplicity of the island’s existence, a stark contrast to the gilded cages I’ve known in the city.  I long for the warmth of your presence, Eleanor, and the quiet comfort of your embrace.  I pray for your health and happiness.

Yours eternally,

Lord Byron”
37:
The Lord Byron’s Residence,

A dismal ruin, grey and cold,
Where shadows cling and silence holds.
The rafters weep with splintered pain,
A testament to loss and stain.

The tapestries, once rich and bright,
Now fade to dust in fading light.
The portraits stare with vacant eyes,
Reflecting grief beneath the skies.

The hearth burns low, a mournful plea,
For warmth and joy, for memory free.
A chilling breeze through broken panes,
Whispers of sorrow, endless strains.

The silence screams a hollow sound,
Where once a life was richly crowned.
A monument to passion lost,
A bitter price, a heavy cost.
38: The world was all before him, where to choose his place of rest, and Providence his guide.
39: We sailed through the Greek Archipelago, aboard one of His Majesty’s vessels, in the year 1812, into the harbor of Myteleume, on the island of that name. The beauty of this place and the plentiful supply of cattle and vegetables encouraged many British ships to visit it – both men of war and merchants; and though it lies rather out of the track for ships bound to Smyrna, its bounties amply repay for the deviation of a voyage. We landed, as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and while the men were employed in watering, and the purser was bargaining with the natives for cattle, we and ourselves toiled to the cave called Homer’s School and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida, we met with and engaged a young Greek as over a guide, who told us he held come from Sicily with an English lord, who led the desolate days previous to our arrival in his fleet. He engaged me as a pilot, and he would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quit Mylylene, where I am likely to get married. He was odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has left an old mansion in chlorine of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six hundred dollars for it (about £250 English currency); and has resided there about fourteen months, though not constantly; for he sells in his felucca very often to the different islands.
40: This caused great excitement and we rushed to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us through the manor. The ground-floor contained four apartments, an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting room, and a bedroom, with a spacious closet attached. The walls were painted green, the tables were made of mahogany, there was a large Myrtle in the center, and a small fountain was beneath, which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a leaning posture; a large couch or sofa completed the room. There were half a dozen English chairs in the hall, and an empty bookcase. There was a single painting. The bedroom had merely a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed quilts and a pillow – the common bed throughout Greece. In the sitting room, we observed a marble recess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large sailor’s chest in the cellar; it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. The tablet was the complete collection of Voltaire’s, Shakespeare’s, Boileau’s, and Rousseau’s works. Voltaire’s Ruins of Empires, Zimmerman’s Germari, Klopstock’s Messiah, Kotzebue’s novels, and Schiller’s play of the Robbers were printed in Parma, 1810. The books were filled with notes, written in Italian and Latin with a pencil. The Messiah was widely written over and marked with slips of paper, and also with remarks.
41: The old man said, “The Lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with the others; but, said he, “there they must lie until his return; for he is so particular that if I were to move one thing without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; here, otherways very good.” I once did him a service, and I have the produce of this farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty zechin’s which I pay to an aged Armenian who retires in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don’t know for what reason.
42: The appearance of the house externally pleased. The portico was fifteen paces long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars with six-lack plinth and fret-work corniches, (as it is now customary in Grecian architecture,) were considerably larger than the rooms. The roof, surrounded by a light slate balustrade, was covered by a fine tapestry curtain, beneath an awning of strong coarse linen. The houses are mostly furnished, and Greeks gather in the evenings to smoke light wines, such as “Lachryma Christi,” eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breeze.
43: On the left hand as we entered the house, a small streamlet glided away, grapes, oranges, and limes were clustering together on its borders, and under the shade of two large myrtle bushes, a marble seat with an ornamental wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the lord passed merry of his evenings and nights until twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. I suppose, the old man said, “praying” for he was very devout, and always attended our church twice a week, besides Sundays.
44: The vineyards stretched out before me, leading my gaze to Mount Calaca, covered with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in majestic decay. A small stream issuing from the ruins descended in broken cascades, until it was lost in the woods, farther than the mouritsian base. The sea was smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadowed by a single cloud, terminated the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty oaks and palm trees, several small islands were distinctly observed, shrouded in the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I was rarely impressed by Dominick, as none knew his name, and his banker, who had gone to Candia, was the only one who knew him. The Armenians, we learned several particulars of the isolated lord. He had portioned eight young girls when he was last on the island, and then danced with them at the wedding feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the women who weave these articles. He bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testaments to the party children. He appeared to us, from all we collected, to be a very conscientious and benevolent character. We learned one thing, and our old friend at the tailor thought it proper not to discard. He had a beautiful granddaughter, with whom he often saw walking on the sea. He bought her a piano and taught her to play.
45: Such was the information with which we departed from the peaceful isle of Mykonos; our imaginations all on the rack, guessing who this rambler in Greece could be. He had money; it was evident that he possessed a philanthropic disposition, and all the peculiar qualities which marked peculiar genius. We arrived in Palermo, and all our doubts were dispelled. Failing in company with Mr. Foster, the architect, a pupil of Wyatt’s, who had been traveling in Egypt and Greece, “The individual,” said he, “about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I beheld him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited his at Mytilene.” We had never then heard of his lordship’s fame, as we had been some years from home; but “Child Harold” being put into our hands we recognized the recluse of Calca in every page. We deeply regretted not being more curious in our researches at the cottage, but we reconciled ourselves with the idea of returning to Myteleene on some future day; but that day will never return. I believe this is a rather formal and somewhat dramatic statement. He has been described as an unemotional disposition, unlike human nature, or contributing to its ailments, or adding to its pleasures. The facts are directly opposite. All the finer feelings of the heart seem to be in his lordship’s poems. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity guide all his actions; and his courting the repose of solitude is another reason for marking him as a being on whose heart Religion hath thrown her mantle, and over whosehead benevolence hath thrown her ointment. A patriot must be proud of his country. I understand. Reports should be treated with caution, particularly when directed against a man’s moral integrity; and any one daring to justify himself before that awful tribunal where all must appear, shall censure the errors as a fellow mortal. Byron’s genius is admirable. To live in solitude and shun the world’s praise is the surest evidence of a virtuous heart and self-approved conscience.
